And, there is non-erosive gastritis, for which the most common cause is a Helicobacter pylori infection.  Helicobacter pylori colonizes the stomachs of more than half of the world's population, and the infection continues to play a key role in the pathogenesis of a number of gastroduodenal diseases.  Colonization of the gastric mucosa with Helicobacter pylori results in the development of chronic gastritis in infected individuals and, in a subset of patients, chronic gastritis progresses to complications .  However, more than 80% of individuals infected with the bacterium are asymptomatic and it has been postulated that it may play an important role in the natural stomach ecology. Gastritis may also develop after major surgery or traumatic injury , burns , or severe infections
response: You're welcome. Don't hesitate to see a doctor for a proper diagnosis and treatment.

dialog: Hi Medi, I just wanted to know more about the causes of non-erosive gastritis.
Hi there, the most common cause of non-erosive gastritis is a Helicobacter pylori infection.
Why does this infection cause gastritis?
Helicobacter pylori colonizes the stomach lining and triggers an immune response that can lead to inflammation and damage to the stomach lining.
I see. Is there any way to prevent getting a Helicobacter pylori infection?
It can be difficult to prevent because it's so common, but practicing good hygiene and avoiding contaminated food and water can help reduce the risk of infection.
Okay, thank you for the information.
You're welcome. Let me know if you have any other questions.
Actually, one more question. Can non-erosive gastritis lead to complications?

dialog: Hi Medi, I recently underwent a surgical procedure and was wondering if there are any dietary changes I should make.
Hi, congratulations on getting through the procedure. What kind of surgery did you have?
I had my gallbladder removed.
For the first few weeks after surgery, it's best to stick to a low-fat diet to avoid stressing your digestive system. Gradually add more fat back into your diet as tolerated.
Got it. Are there any foods I should avoid entirely?
Yes, you should avoid high-fat and greasy foods, as well as dairy, spicy foods, and caffeine. Stick to bland, easy-to-digest foods like cooked vegetables, lean protein, and whole grains.
Thanks for the advice. Is there anything else I should do to aid in my recovery?
Yes, getting plenty of rest and light exercise, like walking, can help speed up the recovery process.
Okay, thank you for your help.
